headline: In This Buffalo Suburb, a Brush With Mall Security Can Lead to Arrest by Border Patrol
summary: At least five immigration arrests in Cheektowaga this year originated from calls by Walden Galleria Macy's security guards to local police, highlighting the involvement of private security and local law enforcement in immigration enforcement and raising policy questions about local police collaboration with federal immigration authorities.

headline: Indiana unveils multi-year rural health plan in newly released federal application
summary: Indiana's 167-page proposal for the federal Rural Health Transformation Program outlines 12 initiatives to stabilize 52 rural hospitals facing service cuts and address chronic disease, provider shortages, and behavioral health gaps across 64 counties; the plan includes $600 million in regional grants, a 24/7 patient transfer coordination hub, and connecting 450 rural facilities to the state's health information exchange with AI tools; jointly led by the Family and Social Services Administration and Department of Health, the proposal targets high rates of diabetes, hypertension, and maternity service closures; awards will be decided by December 31, with regional grants launching March 2026 if approved; the initiative comes as federal Medicaid cuts threaten $155 billion in rural healthcare funding nationally.

headline: Feds move to vacate prison orders, judgments on Casada, Cothren
summary: The corruption case involving racist texting by Tennessee officials, later pardoned by President Trump, highlights how discriminatory attitudes among government officials could potentially influence immigration enforcement policies and practices at the state or federal level.

headline: Vaccine rates in this South Carolina county lagged for years. Then measles struck.
summary: South Carolina's measles outbreak in Spartanburg County (50+ cases since October) reflects critically low vaccination rates (90% vs. required 95%) amid a sixfold increase in religious exemptions over the past decade, driven by "health freedom" ideology from conservative politicians including HHS Secretary RFK Jr. and Governor Henry McMaster, who opposes mandates. The state Department of Public Health's response has been notably subdued, with pop-up clinics poorly attended and only 44 MMR doses administered via mobile units—a stark contrast to earlier COVID-19 vaccine campaigns. In April, Republican senators rejected Dr. Edward Simmer's confirmation as health director due to his COVID-19 vaccine promotion, demonstrating how pandemic polarization now undermines routine immunization efforts. This political resistance, combined with misinformation from nonmedical leaders, has created a chilling effect that leaves communities vulnerable to escalating outbreaks of preventable diseases.

headline: State police, emergency management score additional funding in Pa.’s budget
summary: Pennsylvania's resolved budget stalemate provided a $69.3 million increase for State Police operations to fund four new cadet classes. The Emergency Management disaster response fund doubled from $20 million to $40 million to offset reduced federal support. The Commonwealth Disaster Recovery Assistance Program received a $5 million increase. The budget also reauthorized a $1.95 monthly 911 phone surcharge until January 31, 2029.

headline: Some DACA recipients have been arrested in Trump’s immigration crackdown
summary: DACA supporters rallied outside a Houston federal courthouse on June 1, 2023, following a hearing on the program, demonstrating advocacy for immigration protections and highlighting ongoing governmental and legal disputes over deportation relief policies for childhood arrivals.

headline: Louisiana Surgeon General Ralph Abraham, a vaccine skeptic, tapped for No. 2 post at CDC
summary: Louisiana Surgeon General Ralph Abraham, who eliminated the state's vaccine promotion program and mass vaccination events, has been appointed to the CDC's second-highest position; his tenure was marked by delayed public guidance during a whooping cough outbreak that killed two infants, promotion of debunked COVID-19 treatments, and citation of anti-vaccine talking points, despite overseeing the state's public health efforts and receiving praise from Governor Jeff Landry, who shares his vaccine skepticism.

headline: Child care workers are building a network of resistance against ICE
summary: ICE arrest of a child care worker at Chicago's Rayito de Sol daycare sparked demonstrations across the city and catalyzed rapid formation of resistance networks, including parent-organized safe passage patrols with whistles, escort systems for teachers, and encrypted communication channels. The mobilization follows the Trump administration's removal of "sensitive locations" protections that previously restricted ICE enforcement at schools and daycares, forcing child care providers to create emergency protocols for what advocates call a "man-made disaster." Community members have established legal clinics, meal trains, and fundraising campaigns supporting detained workers, while home-based providers report 70% of their families lack permanent legal status. The networks involve both citizens and non-citizens organizing protective measures, with parents serving as lookouts and escorts during drop-off and pickup times. This represents a direct community response to federal immigration policy changes targeting childcare facilities, which serve as critical infrastructure for both economic stability and family unity.

headline: More Idahoans are getting sick after drinking raw milk, state says
summary: Idaho state and local health officials, including the Department of Health and Welfare, are investigating at least 26 raw milk-related illnesses since August, with 23 Campylobacter cases (six in children under 12) and three STEC infections; officials urge symptomatic individuals to seek medical care and report illnesses to their local public health district, highlighting the public health risks of unpasteurized dairy products.

headline: Idaho may need to find $600 million to $1 billion for next year’s state budget
summary: Idaho faces a projected $58.3 million deficit for FY 2026 and a potential $600 million-$1 billion gap for FY 2027 due to revenue shortfalls, $3.2 billion in recent tax cuts, and $200-284 million in costs if the state conforms to federal tax changes; legislative leaders vow to balance the budget through program cuts or tapping $1.7 billion in reserves, though Democrats warn of catastrophic impacts and observers note most lawmakers lack experience with major budget reductions.

headline: McKee’s approval sinks lower; Foulkes leads in early Democratic primary polling
summary: The University of New Hampshire Survey Center's Ocean State Poll finds 42% of likely Democratic primary voters undecided for Rhode Island's 2026 gubernatorial race, with Helena Foulkes leading at 29% over House Speaker Shekarchi (13%) and incumbent Gov. McKee (11%, down from 19% in September); McKee suffers from broad dissatisfaction with only 21% approving his performance and 68% rating his Washington Bridge communications as "poor" or "very poor," while 67% support state intervention to keep Roger Williams and Fatima hospitals open.

headline: Homeland Security wants state driver’s license data for sweeping citizenship program
summary: The Trump administration's Department of Homeland Security is seeking access to state driver's license data through the Nlets law enforcement network to expand its SAVE citizenship verification program for immigration enforcement and voter fraud investigations, prompting Democratic-led states including Illinois, Massachusetts, Minnesota, New York, and Washington to block ICE access, while advocacy groups warn this federal data collection could enable mass surveillance of immigrant communities and create a centralized citizenship database, intensifying the political conflict between states and the federal government over immigration enforcement authority and privacy rights.

headline: ICE ‘routinely’ made unlawful warrantless arrests in Colorado, federal judge finds
summary: A federal judge in Denver ordered the Trump administration to halt routine warrantless immigration arrests in Colorado that violate federal law requiring proof of flight risk, ruling that Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem and immigration officials have engaged in a "policy, pattern, and/or practice" of illegal arrests. The injunction requires officers to document specific, particularized facts supporting flight risk determinations and to consider the "totality of circumstances," prohibiting the use of mere unlawful presence as sufficient justification. The court granted provisional class-action status, extending protections to all individuals unlawfully arrested in Colorado since January 20, 2025. The ruling directly challenges President Trump's pledge to conduct the largest domestic deportation operation in U.S. history targeting 12 million undocumented immigrants. The judge declined to mandate training requirements but allowed plaintiffs to renew that request if compliance issues arise.

headline: FBI requests interview with Colorado’s Rep. Crow over call for troops to defy illegal orders
summary: Rep. Jason Crow and congressional Democrats' video urging military/intelligence personnel to refuse illegal orders constitutes explicit advocacy for civil disobedience within government ranks, prompting FBI investigations, presidential accusations of sedition punishable by death—including calls for hanging—and increased threats against lawmakers, demonstrating how political speech encouraging institutional civil disobedience can trigger severe governmental retaliation.

headline: Another Iowa jail sued over DOJ policy on detaining immigrants without bond
summary: The Trump administration's July 2025 policy mandating detention without bond for individuals who entered the U.S. without inspection—reversing a 30-year precedent of bond hearings for those living in the country—has triggered hundreds of federal lawsuits, including one by an Uzbek asylum-seeker detained in Iowa's Hardin County Jail; while federal district courts have overwhelmingly ruled that detainees are entitled to bond hearings, immigration judges continue to deny them under the new interpretation, creating a legal conflict between court systems.

headline: Third unvaccinated Kentucky baby dies of whooping cough
summary: Kentucky is experiencing its largest pertussis outbreak since 2012, with 566 cases and three infant deaths in the past 12 months—all involving unvaccinated infants and mothers—prompting the state Department of Public Health to urge vaccination as rates decline. Only 86% of kindergarteners and 85% of seventh-graders are current on required whooping cough vaccines, despite school vaccination mandates. Dr. Steven Stack, secretary of the Cabinet for Health and Family Services, called for all Kentuckians to update immunizations, emphasizing that vaccination protects both individuals and communities. The department recommends DTaP/Tdap vaccines beginning at 2 months, with specific schedules for pregnant women, children, and adults every 10 years. Public health officials also advise handwashing, covering coughs, and staying home when sick to prevent further spread.

headline: State audit claims 2023 maternity unit closure in Leominster was preventable
summary: A state audit found UMass Memorial Health could not document how it spent $6.2 million in COVID relief grants, while its closure of a Leominster maternity unit—citing workforce shortages—has created health disparities for MassHealth patients and strained emergency services with increased ambulance births. The auditor argued the funds could have been used to retain maternity staff and maintain services, while the hospital claims the money went to frontline worker bonuses during the pandemic's peak. The Executive Office of Health and Human Services clarified that supporting maternity care would have been a permissible use of the American Rescue Plan Act funds. The closure is part of a broader pattern of service reductions, including pediatric, mental health, and primary care programs. The audit recommends improved accounting for state funds and investing in essential services to protect regional healthcare access.

outlet: News From The States - Fair. Fearless. Free.
headline: Trump shedding support among Latino voters, survey finds
summary: A Pew Research Center poll of over 5,500 Hispanic adults found 70% disapprove of President Trump's record, with 65% disapproving of his immigration policies and 61% saying his policies worsened the economy. The survey shows 71% believe the administration does too much on deportations (up from 56% in March), while 59% have witnessed ICE raids and over half worry about deportation. Nearly half (49%) expect the economy to worsen, and one-third struggled to afford groceries, medical care, or housing. Latino views remain divided by 2024 vote choice, though support among Trump voters has declined. This marks the first time in nearly two decades that most Hispanics report their situation has worsened.
